author: @jsh3288
text: You should have mentioned that if you want to modify the original value passed through a function you need to make it a pointer/reference. Otherwise it will be creating a clone temporary variable and change that one instead of changing the actual variable at the location of memory(This is the reason for pointers entirely)

author: @FredrikChristenson
text: Great explanation of pointers.  I would suggest that there could be a value in explaining why someone would use them, in this video we got a great example of how they work but knowing the how without the why is only half of the story.  I am not an expert but I am pretty sure pointers most common use case is for when you want to avoid creating copies of a value in memory and simply always reference the same address of a value, this makes a lot of sense if you for example want to keep down your programs memory usage or if you create a struct where you want to change value on a specific instance without recreating the struct in memory?
